kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_1: The Controller multiblock must fit in a 7x7x7 area.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_2: A Controller block can only touch up to 3 other Controller blocks.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_3: Placing a fourth Controller will disrupt the network.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_4: Something like this is the most efficient design.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_5: This setup has 48 easily-accessible sides, enough for 1536 channels!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_6: It's highly recommended to use P2P Tunnels.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_7: The middle blocks can each connect to 4 P2P Tunnels!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_multiblock.text_8: Including the center sides, there are 72 faces, enough for 2304 channels!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_1: The ME Controller is the brain of the network.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_10: Color your Cables to keep them separate.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_3: Done properly, a single Controller can support 192 channels
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_5: You might think, "Why not just add another Controller wherever?"
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_7: Having two separate Controllers will disrupt the network, shutting the whole thing down.
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_8: However, placing Controllers together will form a multiblock!
kubejs.ponder.ae2_single.text_9: The more faces, the more channels!
kubejs.ponder.hephaestus_forge_construct: Ensure You Have A Clear Surface
Place Arcane Polished Darkstone In This Formation
Surround The Center Piece Of Arcane Polished Darkstone With Chiseled Arcane Polished Darkstone
Fill In The Rest With Polished Darkstone
Once Again, Ensure You Have A Clear Surface Around Your Base
Now, Place A Smithing Table In The Centre Of The Base
kubejs.ponder.hephaestus_forge_setup.tex: Now You Have Constructed Your Forge You'll Need To Set It Up For Rituals!
Pedestals Will Be Required To Create Rituals.
The Hephaestus Forge Is Useless Without A Source Of Aureal.
Construct This Structure Near Your Forge.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_1: Spatial IO costs a large amount of energy, especially for bigger structures.
You can keep adding more lines for even higher efficiency.
With these, it's at 66.66% effiency, costing 7.92 million FE.
Additional Pylons can also be vertical!
With these, the SCS is at 100% efficiency, and only costs 1.62 million FE!
Each line of Pylons takes up a channel.
While this isn't a problem for smaller or less efficient SCSs, larger ones will need a Controller.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_2: This SCS is 8x7x8, and costs a massive 48,600,000 FE!
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_3: Each SCS has an "Efficiency" percentage, visible in the IO Port.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_4: This SCS has an efficiency of 28.57%, which is why it costs so much.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_5: If we can raise the efficiency, we can lower the FE cost!
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_6: Add another line of Pylons, parallel to one of the existing ones.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_7: The efficiency is now 38.09%, and the cost is now 30.88 million FE.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_8: You don't have to put a full line, but it's more efficient to.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_big.text_9: Adding only two brings the efficiency to only 30.95%, and the cost to 43.39 million FE.
kubejs.ponder.spatial_storage_simple.tex: AE2's Spatial Storage allows you to take an area in the world and store it digitally.
Traditionally, the Pylons are placed like this...
...but for visibility's sake, let's keep it here.
So long as they're surrounding the same area, it doesn't matter.
Attach the Pylons to the same network...
...and connect a Spatial IO Port as well.
This entire structure is called the Spatial Containment Structure.
You can only have one per network...
...though really, these are often single-use only.
Insert a Spatial Storage Cell...
...give it a Redstone signal...
The smallest Spatial Storage Cell can hold a 2x2x2 volume, and the largest can hold up to a 128x128x128.
...and the structure is stored into the Disk!
Now you can take this filled Disk and bring it home.
Recreate the Spatial Containment Structure.
Insert the Spatial Storage Cell...
...give it a Redstone signal...
...and the structure will exit the Cell!
A note: Entities (including Players) can also get caught!
If you accidentally get caught in the Spatial Storage dimension, you will be STUCK THERE!
The only way to get back out is teleportation, commands, death, or getting someone/something in the overworld to un-store you.
We'll go over the smallest one first.
Say we find some Flawless Budding Certus Quartz.
We want to bring it home, but we can't safely mine it.
So, instead we'll use Spatial Storage!
Place Spatial Pylons around the area you want to move.
They must by one block longer than the area being moved!
Here, since we're moving a 2x2x2 volume, each Pylon must be 3 long.
createblock.ponder.chromatic_dust.text_1: Chromatic Dust can be created by a process called Soaking
createblock.ponder.chromatic_dust.text_2: Drop a piece of Cinder Flour into the liquid
